answers.answer: Just a question but did they specifically say hypo or could he be hyper. I ask because hyper usually doesn't gain weight and is energetic and hypo is the opposite

Wow, I'm sorry.  It's bad enough when this stuff hits us but it's unimaginable when it hits our children.I hope that your son's doctors are also checking for antibodies/autoimmune disorders and checking his blood glucose (A1C).Just wondering because I've been through the thyroid issues with my daughter (precancerous thyroid removed at age 16) and Type I diabetes problems with my now-15 year old son.  Some of the things you are mentioning with your son are symptoms of Type I diabetes which is an endocrine autoimmune disorder which *might* impact or affect they thyroid.When they figure out your son's problem, you might want to get your daughter checked too, just in case.  I know dragging both of my kids to the hospital three years ago for thyroid ultrasounds wasn't fun (neither was worrying that my daughter's thyroid would be cancerous) but I wouldn't have rested well if I didn't check them.  I thought I dodged a bullet with my son since his thyroid was perfect - then he developed diabetes.  :-(Hang tough and please keep us posted.

Thanks for all of the feedback.  I haven't seen those sites yet, Graveslady but I will definitely review them.  I don't know if I mentioned it (probably not) but my son is 17 1/2 months old.  That would mean a TSH of 11.0 is quite elevated (I thought the range was to 10.0 but I may have been looking at an adult range).  At least there's one good thing - he went to cardiology today and they said his heart is back to normal (from the Kawasaki Disease) and as long as his platelets are close to normal we can take him off his aspirin (they were very high).They did just a basic thyroid panel yesterday - tsh, t3, t4, free t4 and those results should be back this afternoon along with the platelet count.  If any of the thyroid studies are funky we'll be going to endocrine again (before was for growth studies) and I'll make sure they do additional bloodwork.  Once I have the results I'll post and let y'all know.

question: My son's pediatrician called me yesterday to let me know that bloodwork done before Christmas showed that his TSH was up to 11 (it was been normal back in October or November).  The labs were done because his weight gain since he was about 9-10 months has been very poor.  He will gain a little bit and then plateau and then gain a little bit and then plateau.  He has only gained approx. 2 pounds since he was 10 months old (that's in 8 months).  He's only 20# and given his birth weight of 9# he should have reached 20# long ago.I did some research on the internet and while I found that hypothyroidism in infants can cause poor appetite and spotty growth I don't see that he has any of the other symptoms.  He's *extremely* active (we often joke that if he'd sit down more he might gain a little weight), he does have dry skin but not bad, no brittle hair, no yellowing of the skin, etc.  We're going today for a repeat tsh plus t3, t4, etc. He's already being followed by cardiology (for a bout of Kawasaki Disease over Thanksgiving).  He saw endo last fall to rule out a growth disorder and he's currently being worked up by gi for his weight problem (they're the ones who reordered the tsh).  I had really thought that we'd be done with specialists for him this month.  *sigh*  I still have hope that 2007 will be better for my family health-wise but this is not a promising start.  Should I be worried at all about this elevated tsh?  I know he's at higher risk because of my thyroid problems.  If he is hypo should I get my daughter checked, too?  Thanks.
